issue.title: Fast way to retrieve all spectra

content.raw:
Hi Tim,

if you don't want to do any filtering, you can use `tandem.read` instead of `tandem.filter`.

The main reason why your code reports less identifications is probably because `tandem.filter` removes all decoys by default (you can change it with `remove_decoy=False`). However, some low-scored identifications can still be filtered out even with `fdr=1`.

Also the total number of IDs will not necessarily be equal to the number of spectra. That would depend on the data and X!Tandem settings. But `tandem.read` will give you everything there is in the file.
content.html:
Hi Tim,

if you don't want to do any filtering, you can use tandem.read instead of tandem.filter.

The main reason why your code reports less identifications is probably because tandem.filter removes all decoys by default (you can change it with remove_decoy=False). However, some low-scored identifications can still be filtered out even with fdr=1.

Also the total number of IDs will not necessarily be equal to the number of spectra. That would depend on the data and X!Tandem settings. But tandem.read will give you everything there is in the file.

issue.title: Fast way to retrieve all spectra

content.raw:
Hi, 

When I use ```tandem.filter``` with a ```decoy_prefix```, I still get decoys back in my proteins. Is this possible or is this a bug? 
The decoy_prefix is correct, since if a use a bogus decoy_prefix, I just get the initial number of IDs back.

Edit: Thanks already for the earlier (and quick!) feedback :)

Best,
T.
content.html:
Hi,

When I use tandem.filter with a decoy_prefix, I still get decoys back in my proteins. Is this possible or is this a bug? The decoy_prefix is correct, since if a use a bogus decoy_prefix, I just get the initial number of IDs back.

Edit: Thanks already for the earlier (and quick!) feedback :)

Best, T.

issue.title: Fast way to retrieve all spectra

content.raw:
Hi Tim,

Decoy proteins may be in the output for a couple of reasons:

1. if you call `tandem.filter` with `remove_decoy=False`;
1. if the peptide is shared between decoy and target proteins. In this case it is not considered a decoy (you should see some targets in the list of alternative proteins);
1. something else, including a bug. If this is the case, please let me know and include the relevant code (a sample file would be great).

Best regards,

Lev
content.html:
Hi Tim,

Decoy proteins may be in the output for a couple of reasons:

  1. if you call tandem.filter with remove_decoy=False;
  2. if the peptide is shared between decoy and target proteins. In this case it is not considered a decoy (you should see some targets in the list of alternative proteins);
  3. something else, including a bug. If this is the case, please let me know and include the relevant code (a sample file would be great).

Best regards,

Lev
